questions.question: What is meant by vibration?
questions.answer: Vibration is the to and fro or back and forth motion of an object about its mean position.

questions.question: How is sound produced?
questions.answer: Sound is produced when an object vibrates and transfers energy to the surrounding medium.

questions.question: What is compression in a sound wave?
questions.answer: Compression is the region where air particles are closer together and pressure is high.

questions.question: What is rarefaction in a sound wave?
questions.answer: Rarefaction is the region where air particles are farther apart and pressure is low.

questions.question: What forms one complete cycle of a sound wave?
questions.answer: One compression and one rarefaction together form one complete cycle of a sound wave.

questions.question: What is frequency of a sound wave?
questions.answer: Frequency is the number of cycles of compression and rarefaction produced per second.

questions.question: What is the unit of frequency?
questions.answer: The unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz).

questions.question: What does 1 Hz frequency mean?
questions.answer: It means one cycle of vibration is completed in one second.

questions.question: What determines the frequency of a tuning fork?
questions.answer: The frequency depends on the length, thickness of prongs and the material of the tuning fork.

questions.question: Why is sound called a longitudinal wave?
questions.answer: Because particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question: Why does sound need a medium to travel?
questions.answer: Sound travels by vibrations of particles of a medium, so a medium is necessary.

questions.question: What happens to sound in vacuum?
questions.answer: Sound cannot travel in vacuum because there are no particles to carry vibrations.

questions.question: What is shown by bell jar experiment?
questions.answer: It shows that sound needs a material medium for generation and propagation.

questions.question: What travels in sound wave: air or disturbance?
questions.answer: The disturbance in the form of compressions and rarefactions travels, not the air itself.

questions.question: What is pitch of sound?
questions.answer: Pitch is the sensation that helps us distinguish between high and low frequency sounds.

questions.question: How is pitch related to frequency?
questions.answer: Higher frequency means higher pitch and lower frequency means lower pitch.

questions.question: Why do different glass cups produce different sounds in Jal-tarang?
questions.answer: Because the height of air column in each glass is different, changing the frequency.

questions.question: Which part vibrates in string instruments?
questions.answer: The stretched strings vibrate to produce sound.

questions.question: How are different notes produced in guitar?
questions.answer: By changing the tension and vibrating length of the strings.

questions.question: Which part vibrates in flute to produce sound?
questions.answer: The air column inside the flute vibrates to produce sound.

questions.question: How are notes changed in flute?
questions.answer: By opening or closing holes and by changing the way of blowing air.

questions.question: Where is larynx located in humans?
questions.answer: Larynx is located at the upper end of the windpipe.

questions.question: What are vocal cords?
questions.answer: Vocal cords are stretched membranes in the larynx that vibrate to produce sound.

questions.question: How is sound produced in human body?
questions.answer: Air from lungs passes through vocal cords causing them to vibrate and produce sound.

questions.question: Why does tightening of vocal cords change voice?
questions.answer: Tight vocal cords vibrate faster, changing the frequency and quality of voice.

questions.question: Why are voices of men and women different?
questions.answer: Because men have longer vocal cords and women have shorter ones.

questions.question: Why do children have shriller voice?
questions.answer: Because children have very short vocal cords which vibrate faster.

questions.question: What is the function of epiglottis?
questions.answer: It closes the air passage during swallowing to prevent food entering windpipe.

questions.question: Which part vibrates in loudspeaker?
questions.answer: The conical screen attached to the coil vibrates to produce sound.

questions.question: What type of energy is converted in loudspeaker?
questions.answer: Electrical energy is converted into sound energy.

questions.question: Why are loudspeakers used in public places?
questions.answer: Because they can produce very loud sound to reach many people.

questions.question: What is sound pollution?
questions.answer: Sound pollution is excessive unwanted sound that affects health and environment.

questions.question: How can sound pollution be reduced?
questions.answer: By limiting loudspeaker use, reducing noise and following noise control rules.

questions.question: What is loudness of sound?
questions.answer: Loudness is the measure of how strong or weak a sound appears to us.

questions.question: In which unit is loudness measured?
questions.answer: Loudness is measured in decibel (dB).

questions.question: Why is sound above 100 dB harmful?
questions.answer: Because it can damage ears and affect human health.

questions.question: Why cannot astronauts hear each other on moon?
questions.answer: Because there is no atmosphere on moon to carry sound waves.

questions.question: What kind of waves are used in mobile communication?
questions.answer: Electromagnetic waves are used which do not need medium.

questions.question: What is meant by amplitude of sound wave?
questions.answer: Amplitude is the maximum displacement of particles from their mean position.

questions.question: Which property of sound depends on amplitude?
questions.answer: Loudness of sound depends on amplitude.

questions.question: What happens to sound level as distance increases?
questions.answer: Sound level decreases as distance from source increases.

questions.question: What is meant by sound note?
questions.answer: Sound note is a sound produced with a definite frequency.

questions.question: Which instruments use blown air for sound?
questions.answer: Flute and shehnai use blown air to produce sound.

questions.question: Which instruments use strings for sound production?
questions.answer: Sitar, guitar and violin use strings to produce sound.

questions.question: What happens when tuning fork prongs move apart?
questions.answer: Air is compressed and a compression region is formed.

questions.question: What happens when tuning fork prongs come closer?
questions.answer: Air pressure decreases forming rarefaction.

questions.question: What causes ear-drum to vibrate?
questions.answer: Sound waves reaching the ear cause ear-drum to vibrate.

questions.question: What is the role of brain in hearing?
questions.answer: Brain interprets signals from ear and gives sensation of sound.

questions.question: What is meant by medium?
questions.answer: Medium is the material through which sound travels, like air, water or solids.

questions.question: Can sound travel through solids?
questions.answer: Yes, sound can travel through solids as vibrations pass through particles.

questions.question: Why can we hear through toy telephone?
questions.answer: Because vibrations travel through the stretched thread or wire.

questions.question: What do dancing grains on rubber sheet show?
questions.answer: They show that sound produces vibrations.

questions.question: What is windpipe also called?
questions.answer: Windpipe is also called trachea.

questions.question: What is esophagus?
questions.answer: Esophagus is the food pipe that carries food to stomach.

questions.question: Why should we avoid unnecessary noise?
questions.answer: To protect health and reduce sound pollution.

questions.question: What happens if vocal cords do not vibrate?
questions.answer: No sound will be produced.

questions.question: What produces sound in tuning fork?
questions.answer: Vibration of metal prongs produces sound.

questions.question: Why is sound weaker in vacuum jar?
questions.answer: Because air is removed, so vibrations cannot travel effectively.

questions.question: What is meant by sound wave propagation?
questions.answer: It is the transfer of compressions and rarefactions through a medium.

questions.question: Which wave does not need medium?
questions.answer: Electromagnetic waves do not need medium.

questions.question: What is the function of coil in loudspeaker?
questions.answer: It moves due to magnetic field and causes screen to vibrate.

questions.question: Why should loudness of loudspeaker be limited?
questions.answer: To prevent harm to ears and avoid sound pollution.

questions.question: What is meant by sound energy?
questions.answer: Sound energy is energy carried by sound waves.

questions.question: What happens when frequency increases?
questions.answer: Sound becomes shriller or higher pitched.

questions.question: What happens when amplitude increases?
questions.answer: Sound becomes louder.

questions.question: Which sound has more pitch: child or adult?
questions.answer: Child's sound has more pitch due to higher frequency.

questions.question: What is meant by sound note generator app?
questions.answer: It is an app used to produce sound of specific frequencies.

questions.question: Why do we feel vibration on throat while speaking?
questions.answer: Because vocal cords vibrate during speech.

questions.question: What is mechanical wave?
questions.answer: A wave that needs a medium for propagation is called mechanical wave.

questions.question: Is sound a mechanical wave?
questions.answer: Yes, sound is a mechanical wave because it needs a medium.

questions.question: Why does tightening rubber strips produce sound?
questions.answer: Because air passing through makes them vibrate.

questions.question: Which part of tuning fork is held steady?
questions.answer: The stem of tuning fork is held steady.

questions.question: What is meant by air column?
questions.answer: Air trapped in a tube or glass that vibrates to produce sound.

questions.question: What determines frequency in air column?
questions.answer: The height or length of the air column determines frequency.

questions.question: What is sound pollution effect on society?
questions.answer: It causes irritation, stress and health problems.

questions.question: Why should we study sound pollution?
questions.answer: To protect environment and social health.

questions.question: What happens if sound is too loud for long time?
questions.answer: It may damage hearing permanently.

questions.question: What is meant by sound propagation speed?
questions.answer: It is the speed at which sound waves travel through a medium.

questions.question: Does sound travel faster in solids or gases?
questions.answer: Sound travels faster in solids than in gases.

questions.question: What is role of magnet in loudspeaker?
questions.answer: It interacts with coil’s magnetic field to cause vibrations.

questions.question: What is meant by sound signal?
questions.answer: It is vibration pattern that reaches ear and is interpreted as sound.

questions.question: What is meant by sound wave energy transfer?
questions.answer: Energy is passed from particle to particle without moving matter.

questions.question: Why is air necessary for hearing normal sound?
questions.answer: Because sound vibrations must travel through air to reach ears.

questions.question: What produces compression in air?
questions.answer: Forward motion of vibrating object produces compression.

questions.question: What produces rarefaction in air?
questions.answer: Backward motion of vibrating object produces rarefaction.

questions.question: Why does flute produce different notes when holes are closed?
questions.answer: Because length of vibrating air column changes.

questions.question: What is sound wave pattern in air?
questions.answer: Alternating compressions and rarefactions form sound wave pattern.

questions.question: What is sound perception?
questions.answer: It is brain’s interpretation of vibrations received by ear.

questions.question: What is importance of studying sound?
questions.answer: To understand communication, music and reduce sound pollution.

questions.question: What happens to sound when air density is high?
questions.answer: Compressions are stronger and sound transmission is effective.

questions.question: Why do we feel sound vibrations in loudspeaker?
questions.answer: Because the screen vibrates strongly producing sound waves.

questions.question: What is meant by mechanical vibration?
questions.answer: It is physical back and forth motion of an object.

questions.question: Why is sound not heard in space?
questions.answer: Because space has no medium to transmit sound.

questions.question: What is sound intensity?
questions.answer: It is amount of sound energy passing through area per second.

questions.question: What is meant by sound wave cycle?
questions.answer: It is one complete compression and rarefaction sequence.

questions.question: Why do musical instruments need tuning?
questions.answer: To adjust frequency and produce correct musical notes.

questions.question: What is role of muscles in vocal cords?
questions.answer: They tighten or loosen cords to change voice.

questions.question: Why does shouting damage voice?
questions.answer: Because it strains vocal cords due to strong vibrations.

questions.question: What is sound communication?
questions.answer: Transfer of information using sound waves.

questions.question: Why should sound level be controlled in cities?
questions.answer: To reduce noise pollution and protect public health.
